narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a great deal over this course. I learned about our solar system, why the planets move the way they do, and how our atmosphere  and surrounding celestial objects affect day to day life on earth. I learned about the properties of planets and stars, how they form, how they die, and how their composition affects their activity and appearance. I also learned how to calculate a number of these properties, including distance, mass, luminosity, brightness, and many others.
Learned of foundational astronomy content
Knowledge about celestial bodies and ways of measuring things about them.

well, learned stuff about planets & stars, as advertised.  but, the skill i learned MOST from the experience of taking a Mike class is to TRUST coursetable when it says a prof is unexpectedly RUDE. :( big yikes. coursetable was right :( :(

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I thought that this course was pretty much run to perfection. The spacing of work, especially with the time constraint of a summer course, was definitely a strong point. We covered a great deal of material in a short time. The one thing I wish we'd talked about a bit more was locating stars and planets, as in learning to find where they are by looking up at our sky.
I really liked the flipped classroom- class sessions more interactive and made more sense given the limited time available in a summer session.

Strengths: Flipped class model allows for better comprehension of course topics.
Weaknesses: Way too much content in too little time.

Strengths? sadly negated by the BIG weakness.
Weakness: Sorry to say this, but the professor himself. He's got the propensity to be a bit Rude and Condescending when you least expect it. He's book-smart but CANNOT read the room when it comes to students' human emotions.

Expect heavy passive-aggressive condescension from him if you're less than perfect. If you give an answer in class that's not on the right track, he's known to go "Woahhh, I only gave you One sig fig and somehow your answer has EIGHT! How'd you get THAT level of precision?". He said things like that to multiple students, multiple times, in front of the WHOLE class.

...Also, future students  DON'T submit anything late; there's a solid likelihood he'll unexpectedly tank your grade.

Unironically, I should've listened to other students' past CourseTable entries about his bits of unexpected rudeness.
Decent class, weakened by an unexpectedly-patronizing professor. Emotionally TAXING.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. As someone who has very little interest in science, I found this course engaging, and learned a lot of things that I'm glad I now know. I think everyone should have a basic understanding for why the earth is the way it is, and how celestial objects function and interact. I also think that this course was manageable over zoom, and I think it is a good way to earn science credit if you need it.
Definitely, it was a very interesting and engaging course.
Absolutely- a great introduction to astronomy
Yes if u need a QR
Yes, I would certainly recommend a class with Dr. Faison. He is great.
Yes if you're not doing anything else over the summer or are willing to dedicate great amounts of time to one class for a month.

Not in THIS galaxy. Future students: I'm begging you, be CAUTIOUS before considering taking a Michael Faison class.
He SEEMS nice, but he's got the propensity to be a bit Rude and Condescending when you least expect it. Expect heavy passive-aggressive condescension from him if you're less than perfect.

If you give an answer in class that's not on the right track, he's known to go "Woahhh, I only gave you One sig fig and somehow your answer has EIGHT! How'd you get THAT level of precision?". He said things like that to multiple students, multiple times, in front of the WHOLE class.

...Also, future students  DON'T submit anything late; there's a solid likelihood he'll unexpectedly tank your grade.

Unironically, I should've listened to other students' past CourseTable entries about his bits of unexpected rudeness.
Decent class, weakened by an unexpectedly-patronizing professor. Emotionally TAXING.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: Processes used to measure distance between stars and planets can be used in surveying on Earth.
